Fig. 1 Schematic representation of the targeted chemical functionalization of GO with API. Fig. 2 Schematic of the L/L interface method for GOIMZ2 and the deposition of the film in both sides of the glass. Fig. 3 FTIR spectra on (A) KBr pellet and (B) SeZn accessory. Fig. 4 TGA curves for GO, GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2. Fig. 5 XRD patterns for the functionalized samples. GO and GOIMZ1 was taken using aluminum holder and GOIMZ2 with a thin film accessory. Fig. 6 Raman spectra for GO, GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2. Fig. 7 SEM image for (A) GOIMZ1 and (B) GOIMZ2, (C) digital photograph of GOIMZ2 over glass. Fig. 8 Effect of the number of layers for GOIMZ2 deposited on both sides of a substrate in the reaction with DEDNPP, pH 8.5, 23 °C. Fig. 9 Reaction of DEDNPP and Paraoxon with the nanocatalysts. Fig. 10 Rate enhancements (kcat/kH2O) of several catalysts in the cleavage reaction (homogeneous and heterogeneous) of DEDNPP. *This work. Fig. 11 Recycling procedure for GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2. Fig. 12 Catalytic increments (kcat/kH2O) for the degradation of Paraoxon [55]. *This work. Fig. 13 Proposed mechanism for the reaction for the nanocatalysts with OP. Fig. 14 Comparative life-times (5 t1/2) for DEDNPP and Paraoxon using GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2 (1 mg). Table 1 Catalytic activity of the nanocatalysts with DEDNPP at pH 8.5. Rate constant Comparative a kobs, min−1 kcat, g−1min−1 a kcat/kH2O kcat/kAPI GOIMZ1 1.1×10−4 0.63 1.0×106 0.9 GOIMZ2 6.7×10−4 31.28 4.0×106 44.7 a Considering the reactive API group of the nanocatalyst, calculated by TGA analysis. Orth a ⁎ a Departamento de Química, Universidade Federal do Paraná (UFPR), CP 19032, CEP 81531-980 Curitiba, PR, Brazil Departamento de Química Universidade Federal do Paraná (UFPR) CP 19032 CEP 81531-980 Curitiba PR Brazil b Graphene and Nano-materials Research Center – Mackgraphe – Graphene and Nanomaterials Research Center, Mackenzie Presbyterian University, CEP 01302-907 São Paulo, Brazil Graphene and Nano-materials Research Center – Mackgraphe – Graphene and Nanomaterials Research Center Mackenzie Presbyterian University CEP 01302-907 São Paulo Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Promoting efficient organophoshate (OP) destruction has been of increasing interest, mainly due to their highly toxic nature and broad use as agrochemicals and chemical warfare. It is known that OP destruction can only be accomplished in the presence of catalysts, since they are knowingly stable. Hence, multifunctional materials have been targeted for this purpose since they can combine catalytic sites with features that enable easy handling, sensor projection for monitoring misuse and even large-scaled detoxification methods. Herein, we developed nanocatalysts derived from graphene oxide, which comprises reactive imidazole groups anchored by covalent functionalization. Two approaches were adopted: (i) a mild aqueous reaction leading to a powder, namely GOIMZ1; and (ii) a liquid/liquid interfacial functionalization, resulting in the thin film GOIMZ2. The nanocatalysts were applied in the destruction of OP and in the case of the toxic pesticide Paraoxon, impressive rate enhancements were obtained (108-fold). Both catalysts were consecutively recycled, maintaining overall characteristics. We highlight the feasible handling of the nanocatalysts, that in the case of the powder, it can be easily filtered, washed and reused. For the thin film, the handling is even more practical, since it can be immersed in the contaminated media and separated easier than the powder. Overall, we show novel imidazole-derived nanocatalysts with promising catalytic efficiency towards OP destruction, which have potential for projecting sensors and detoxification processes, especially with the thin films. Keywords Graphene functionalization Organophosphate Thin film Imidazole-derived nanocatalysts 1 Introduction The high growth of world agricultural production is intrinsically linked to an increasing dependence of its products. This number is directly proportional to the use of toxic agrochemicals, resulting in many environmental and health problems [1]. In this context, organophosphates (OP) stands out since it constitutes many pesticides, insecticides and even chemical warfare, justified by its high toxicity. In spite of its prohibited usage in many countries, OP alarms many worries nowadays due to the eminent threat of the large stocks available (agrochemicals and chemical warfare). Albeit, the OP allowed for agriculture are used abusively which knowingly leads to concerning side effects (e.g. cancerogenic), requiring efficient monitoring devices [2]. Moreover, destruction of OP has become of increasing interest as a tool for solving many issues addressed above. In this context, the high PO bond stability of OP is noteworthy which assures it to be potentially active in the environment for a long time, without degrading. Bioinspired by enzymes that promote dephosphorylation processes efficiently (i.e. cleave PO bond) [3], many studies have tried to mimic their action using complex backbones, e.g. biopolymers [4], ionic liquids [5], polyhydroxamate [6] and functionalized fatty acids [7]. Recently a new possibility has aroused by using graphene-derived materials as nanocatalysts for degrading OP. Indeed, the unique physical and chemical properties of graphene materials have been improved by functionalization. Specifically, graphene oxide (GO) has attracted attention due to the several functional groups available for featured covalent functionalization [8,9]. Some promising applications by this means include water treatment [10], catalysis [11], adsorption [12], sensor [13], energy storage [14], solar cells [15], Surface Enhancement Raman Spectroscopy (SERS) substrates [16], among others [8,17]. Previously, we reported the functionalization of GO with cysteamine groups, targeted at the carboxylic acid sites through stable amide bonds. The thiolated nanocatalyst showed high rate enhancements for the cleavage of the OP diethyl 2,4-dinitrophenyl phosphate (DEDNPP), nearly 105–fold compared to the spontaneous reaction [18]. This efficiency was attributed to an enzymatic-like mechanism by reactive thiol groups towards phosphorus atom, which regenerates the catalyst and also to synergism between the graphene backbone (i.e. functional groups and hydrophobic moieties). Imidazole (IMZ) group is particularly interesting given its high reactivity against OP as shown by its presence in many enzymatic active sites such as in acetylcholine esterase [19], chymotrypsin [20] and trypsin [21]. Indeed, IMZ can act by multiple catalytic pathways: nucleophilic, basic and acid, and under fairly mild conditions (i.e. aqueous pH 7) [22]. Innumerous studies described the functionalization of different materials with IMZ pursuing artificial enzymes (e.g. peptide amphiphiles [21], poly(ethylenimine) derivatives [23], polymer lattices [24]), but no study with graphene-based nanocatalysts is reported. Hence, herein we focused on obtaining novel IMZ-derived nanocatalyst derived from GO for OP destruction. Compared to the previous reported thiolated nanocatalyst [18], IMZ has the advantage of having significantly higher chemical stability and catalytic versatility in contrast to thiol groups. In addition, we aimed to produce the materials as both powder and thin film deposited over several substrates. In fact, graphene-based materials presented as powder is commonly reported, although, to the best of our knowledge, not with IMZ groups. Furthermore, pursuing facile applications of the nanocatalyst, we aimed thin film production by a novel approach developed in our group. Most techniques described for graphene-based thin films rely on layer by layer [25,26], spin [27] and dip coating [28], all which require several steps and are hard to control thickness and/or heterogeneity. A simple one-pot alternative is the liquid/liquid interfacial method, where homogenous self-assembled thin films are obtained from liquid/liquid (L/L) interfaces (aqueous/organic solvent) [29], that has potentiated many applications e.g. transparent and flexible electrodes [30], batteries [31], electrochromism [31,32], sensors [30,31], SERS substrates [16], supercapacitor [33], among others. The L/L interfacial method was applied before by our group in the synthesis of several materials, however recently we related two novel approaches to obtain GO directly thiolated followed by the synthesis of a nanocomposite with silver nanoparticle. The film was applied for the cleavage of the toxic pesticide diethyl 4-nitrophenyl phosphate (Paraoxon) showing a high catalytic activity (106 fold) and was also applied as SERS substrates sensors for nitrophenols and for 4-aminothiophenol. The multiple functions of this material allowed a new class of sensors and catalyst for dephosphorylation reactions [34]. Recently we reported a synthetic approach based on the chemical functionalization of GO with 1-(3-aminopropyl)imidazole (API) through amide bonds, using 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl) carbodiimide (EDC) and N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS) for activating the carboxylate sites of GO, Fig. 1 [35]. The powder material obtained by that route (GOIMZ1) was employed for a specific study focused on the pK a determination of different graphene-based materials, demonstrating a novel tool to validate chemical functionalization [35]. Herein, we developed an innovative route to directly obtain the IMZ-functionalized GO also as thin film easily transferable to different substrates (GOIMZ2), and demonstrate for the first time the expressive application of both materials (GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2) as nanocatalysts for OP destruction. Specifically, we evaluated degradation of the model DENDPP and the toxic pesticide Paraoxon. 2 Experimental details GO was synthesized following a modified Hummers method [36]. Paraoxon was obtained commercially, while DEDNPP was synthesized according to a previous report [37]. The synthesis of GOIMZ1 was carried out as previously reported [35]. 2.1 Synthesis of GOIMZ2 GOIMZ2 was prepared by the liquid-liquid interface route as represented in Fig. 2 [29,36,38]. Initially, a thin film of GO was obtained by mixing an aqueous dispersion (20 mL) of GO (0.031 g mL−1) with toluene (10 mL) in a round-flask 50 mL, subsequently subjected to magnetic stirring (1000 rpm) during 12 h. The system was kept under ice bath, followed by the addition of 30.0 mmol of NHS and EDC, that was kept under magnetic stirring for 1 h. After removing the ice bath, the system was kept for 1 h in room temperature (23.0 °C) before the addition of 3.52 mmol of API and left the mixture under stirring for 12 h. Upon interruption of the magnetic stirring, an emulsion was formed at the liquid-liquid interface. The aqueous phase was repetitively substituted (5 times), with the assistance of micropipette, replacing it with deionized water. The same proceed was repeated for the organic phase replacing it by fresh toluene. In the following, the emulsion was transferred to a beaker containing deionized water, toluene and the target substrate. The film immediately self-assembled at the interface and the deposition consisted of pulling the substrate (glass, quartz, Si; 7.5 cm2) toward the liquid-liquid interface, using a homemade dip-coating equipment that controls the pulling velocity and guarantees steadiness [39]. The transfer occurred automatically on the surface allowing the deposition of a thin, continuous, and transparent film. Deposition was carried on both sides of a substrate, in a vertical position, as shown in Fig. 2. After the deposition, the thin film GOIMZ2 was dried at 70 °C during 1 h. 2.2 Characterization Raman spectra were recorded on a Renishaw Raman Imaging Microprobe System 3000 spectrophotometer using Ar+ laser He-Ne laser (632.8 nm and 1.96 eV) in at least 8 different regions of the samples. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectra (FTIR) were done on a FTIR Bio-Rad spectrophotometer over the range of 4000–400 cm−1, using the KBr pellet method for GOIMZ1 and using a substrate of zinc selenide for GOIMZ2. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å), at 40 kV and 30 mA, at 0.02° scan rate (in 2θ), with a step of 5 s per point. For GOIMZ1, aluminum and glass holder were used. For GOIMZ2, XRD patterns were recorded using a low angle accessory with 0.1° incident angle operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Thermogravimetric analysis and differential scanning calorimetry (TGA/DSC) were carried out on a SDT Q600 equipment (TA Instruments) from TA Instruments under 100 mL min−1 air flow at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were recorded using a MIRA-3 FEG-SEM Tescan with 10 kV voltage and a secondary electrons detector. The samples were analyzed either as powder sprinkled on Cu adhesive tape or as thin film deposited over Si substrates. 2.3 Catalytic studies Reactions of the OP (DEDNPP and Paraoxon) with GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2 followed pseudo-first order conditions. For the reaction of GOIMZ1 with DEDNPP, 1.0 mg of the powder was added to a quartz cuvette, with 3 mL of buffered solution (KHCO3, 0.01 mol L−1). The reaction started by the addition of 15 µL of a stock solution of DEDNPP (3.6 × 10−3 mol L−1), that was kept under magnetic stirring and controlled temperature (23.0 °C). The reaction was followed by a spectrophotometer UV–Vis Shimadzu UV-2501 PC measuring the absorbance in a range of 700–250 nm, verifying the formation of the product 2,4-dinitrophenolate (DNP) at 400 nm. For comparison, analogous study with API and DEDNPP was carried out. For the reaction of GOIMZ2 with DEDNPP, a slightly different procedure was adopted where the thin film of GOIMZ2 deposited on glass was immersed into 40 mL of a buffered solution of KHCO3 (0.01 mol L−1) in a closed container. An aliquot (40 µL) of DEDNPP (3.6 × 10−3 mol L−1 in acetonitrile) was added and the medium was kept under magnetic stirring at 23.0 °C. Consecutively, an aliquot of 3 mL of the solution was taken, its UV–Vis spectrum recorded and returned to the solution. Similarly to GOIMZ1, the formation of DNP at 400 nm was measured. For the reactions of DEDNPP with both GOIMZ1 and GOMZ2, the kinetic profiles were fitted according to pseudo-first order equations using iterative least-squares software. The reactions with Paraoxon were carried out following the product 4-nitrophenol (PNP) at 400 nm by UV–Vis spectroscopy. The procedure was different given Paraoxon high toxicity. For GOIMZ1, a sealed vessel containing 1 mg of the nanocatalyst, with 2 mL of KHCO3 (0.01 mol L−1; pH 8,5) and 10 µL of Paraoxon (0.01 mol L−1 in acetonitrile) was kept under stirring and 23.0 °C. After 20 days, a UV–Vis spectrum was recorded and the degree of consumption and rate constant was calculated relating the absorbance measured with the expected absorbance for total degradation of Paraoxon, considering a pseudo-first behavior. This method has been validated giving the same results and profile (pseudo-first order) than the traditional method following consecutively (i.e. as done with DEDNPP), although avoids constant contact with the toxic OP. For GOIMZ2, the thin film was immersed in a closed container containing 40 mL of a buffered solution of KHCO3 (0.01 mol L−1; pH 8.5) and 25 μL of a stock solution of Paraoxon (1 × 10−3 mol L−1 in acetonitrile) and maintained under magnetic stirring at 23.0 °C. After 20 days, absorbance was measured as described above with GOIMZ1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of GOIMZ To verify the successful functionalization of GO, FTIR spectra (Fig. 3 ) were recorded using KBr pellet and zinc selenide (ZnSe) substrate for GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2, respectively. Indeed, typical bands for GO were observed and are more evident in Fig. 3A, such as of non-oxidized graphitic domains in 1630 cm−1 [40] and some oxygenated groups, νOH and νCO (carboxyl groups), near 3400 cm−1 and 1729 cm−1 respectively. Besides, other bands at 1383 cm−1, 1224 cm−1 and 1060 cm−1 were ascribed to tertiary δCOH, epoxy νCOC and νCO in alkoxy groups, respectively [40,41]. Functionalization was confirmed for GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2, through the appearance of new bands, such as the shoulder around 3293 cm−1 assigned to NH bending, the sharp band ∼1640 cm−1 due to the amide νCO and at 1542 cm−1 and 1427 cm−1 referred to νNH and νCN respectively [41,42]. The later band is not so evident for GOIMZ2, due to the thin film that was deposited on a ZnSe accessory which presents a difference in the refractive index KBr (n = 1.52) and ZnSe (n = 2.4). This can cause reflection loss or even constructive or destructive interference, decreasing the resolution by ZnSe as seen when comparing to GO spectra’s. Nonetheless, overall FTIR analysis confirms that IMZ moieties were anchored on both powder and thin film graphene-derived materials. Fig. 4 shows the thermal degradation data for the graphene-derived materials, assuring that functionalization was accomplished. Initially, the expected mass release of residual water was observed below 100 °C for all samples. Further, the weight loss assigned to the oxygenated groups in the range of 135–195 °C for GO (37%), decreased to 20 and 9% for GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2, respectively, thus confirming successful anchoring of API on the carboxyl groups, with higher degree [40,43]. A new weight loss was observed for the functionalized samples in the range of 303–357 °C ascribed to the decomposition of the IMZ groups [43]. In addition, losses of 22% and 46% for GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2, respectively, showed a higher degree of functionalization for the later, which agrees with its lower loss of oxygenated groups. Therefore, the interfacial functionalization method evidenced a higher efficiency for the proposed functionalization, which usually is desirable since the anchored groups are responsible for the catalytic reactivity, pursued furthermore. Finally, the last stage of mass loss, in temperatures higher than 600 °C, attributed to the pyrolysis of the GO carbon backbone [40] showed the thermal stability trend GOIMZ1 > GO > GOIMZ2. XRD patterns for the obtained materials are given in Fig. 5 . Typically, GO shows a peak at 2θ = 10.63° ascribed to the (0 0 2) planes, which according to Bragg’s law corresponds to an interlayer spacing of 8.32 Å [44]. This interlayer spacing is larger than commonly found for graphite, and corroborates the increase of oxygen groups on the graphitic structure after oxidation. Upon functionalization, XRD data showed significant changes for GOIMZ1, such as the shift of (0 0 2) diffraction peak to 2θ = 8.64°, corresponding to a higher interlayer spacing (10.2 Å), consistent with the presence of API in the graphitic structure [45]. Besides, three other peaks were observed, corresponding to 2θ = 18.9°, 22.0° and 24.1°, which suggest a new stacking of the material. In fact, a similar behavior was observed for thiolated GO [40]. The XRD patterns for GOIMZ2 shows some differences in the XRD patterns as can be seen in the absence at 2θ = 10.03° indicating a breakdown in the initial organization of the GO, which can be associated either with the higher degree of functionalization (as observed previously for highly thiolated GO [40]) or with the non-organized stacks of the GO sheets in the film structure. In addition, a new peak at 2θ = 22.08° (d = 4.03 Å) was observed for GOIMZ2, characteristic of a new structural organization of the material. It should be noted that GOIMZ2 was analyzed using a thin film accessory, hence the peak at 7.87° refers to the accessory. In the case of GOIMZ1 and GO, DRX data are shown with an aluminum holder, but analysis for GO using the thin film accessory are similar (shown in Support Information – SI – Fig. S1). Raman spectroscopy is a powerful tool to identify defects and structural modifications on GO, which can be related to the sample’s functionalization. Fig. 6 depicts the spectra of the samples, exhibiting two characteristics bands of graphitic materials: (i) D band, usually centered around 1350 cm−1, assigned to defects and edge effects on the graphitic domains and (ii) G band, centered at 1580–1590 cm−1, related to CC stretching on the graphitic structure. Besides, at 1605–1620 cm−1 the shoulder denoted as D′ band is also related to defects on the material [46]. Other characteristic bands of graphene-like materials can be seen in the higher frequency region, assigned as 2D band (∼2700 cm−1) and 2G band (3130 cm−1), respectively referring to a phonon resonance, and the D + D′ band at 2936 cm−1 [47]. Intensity ratio between D and G bands (ID/IG) has been used to evaluate the structural defects in the materials [41,48]. Herein, we obtained ratios of 1.78, 2.21 and 3.32 for GO, GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2, respectively, thus attesting the successful functionalization [41,48]. The higher ratio for GOIMZ2 is consistent with its higher degree of functionalization, as indicated by TGA. Fig. 7 (A) shows the SEM image for the sample GOIMZ1, where it’s possible to see that after the functionalization, the sample still maintains the sheet structure typical of materials derived from graphene [9]. Fig. 7(B) shows the SEM image for GOIMZ2, that also evidences the typical sheet-like morphology [9]. Fig. 7(C) illustrates the digital photograph of the glass substrate containing GOIMZ2 where is possible to see the homogeneity and transparency of the film. Imidazole anchoring on GO was successfully achieved and the materials were obtained as in powder and thin film, by direct, one-pot and simple routes. In addition, results show for the film GOIMZ2, a higher degree of functionalization. 3.2 Catalytic studies 3.2.1 Optimizing the thin film deposition of GOIMZ2 Before ongoing the complete catalytic studies, the thin film deposition of GOIMZ2 was optimized targeting enhanced catalysis. Firstly, the thin film deposition proposed herein is novel, using the substrate at the vertical position with both sides being covered with film. Commonly, deposition is reported with the substrate at the horizontal position, with the film deposited on one side [31]. Thus, we deposited the thin film at the horizontal position (one side) and at the vertical position (both sides). As expected, the substrate with both sides deposited showed higher catalytic activity (nearly 22%) towards DEDNPP cleavage, since a larger reactive area is available for reacting. Furthermore, we varied the number of layers of thin film deposited on each side of the substrate. This was carried out by deposition one layer on each side by positioning the substrate at the vertical, which was dried and consecutively used for further depositions. Fig. 8 shows the effect of the number of layers on the value of kobs for the reaction with DEDNPP. Interestingly, an exponential behavior is observed and higher rate constants is observed with increasing number of layers, probably connected with the higher number of reactive sites. From 2 to 4 layers, an abrupt increase was observed, followed by a plateau, hence the stacked material is not enabling more reactive groups. Thus, with 2 layers deposition, not all substrate may be homogenously covered by GOIMZ2, although with 4–8 layers, this is guaranteed and any additional deposition “covers” the previous reactive groups available, so the overall amount of reactive groups doesn’t increase. Thereby, further studies with GOIMZ2 were carried out with 4 layers each side, since above this there is not a significant improvement to justify the more laborious thin film deposition. 3.2.2 Reactivity with a model OP substrate GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2 were evaluated as nanocatalysts in the dephosphorylation reaction of the template OP, DEDNPP and afterwards with the toxic pesticide Paraoxon. In both cases, the formation of the phenolic products (DNP and PNP, Fig. 9 ) were monitored. It should be noted that all reactions were heterogeneous with pseudo-first behavior. Powder GOIMZ1 was maintained under magnetic stirring during the reaction and the solid decanted easily for measuring the reaction product in solution. In the case of the thin film GOIMZ2, it was deposited (four layers) on both sides of a glass substrate and immersed in the reaction medium and also maintained under stirring, without any release of the film to the solution. Table 1 presents the catalytic activity of the nanocatalysts in the cleavage reaction of DEDNPP at pH 8.5. Comparing pseudo-order constants (kobs), GOIMZ2 is slightly better than GOIMZ1, although a more precise way to evaluate activity is considering the reactive IMZ groups on GO surface. In addition, GOIMZ2 thin film employs a lower amount of catalyst (∼0.0575 mg), in contrast to GOIMZ1 (∼1 mg). Hence, rate constant is also presented considering the mass of reactive group obtained by TGA, namely kcat, that evidenced a significantly higher activity for GOIMZ2 thin film. Comparing to the spontaneous reaction, both GOIMZ showed impressive rate enhancements, ∼106-fold. Another interesting comparison is with the homogenous reaction comprising the reactive group API anchored on GOIMZ. In this case, kcat/kAPI showed similar activity of GOIMZ1 and API, which actually surprises since most homogenous reactions are faster than analogous heterogeneous reaction [49,50]. Although, with GOIMZ2, the heterogeneous reaction was nearly 45-fold faster than with API, confirming the higher efficiency of the thin film nanocatalyst. Overall, the heterogeneous reactions evaluated with the nanocatalysts evidence that besides the known reactivity of API towards OP, a synergistic effect of this group with GO backbone should explain the rate enhancements. It is important to point out that GO does not have significant catalytic activity, presented in SI Fig. S2, evidencing the potential of the materials as a nanocatalyst. Fig. 10 presents rate enhancements for the cleavage reaction of DEDNPP with several catalysts reported in the literature and compared to our results [4,6,18,34,37]. Indeed, the nanocatalyst proposed herein present among the highest increment reported, even considering homogenous catalysts of complex nature, such as polymers. The higher catalytic activity for GOIMZ2 is not clear, but can possibly be linked to a higher availability of the functional groups on the thin film to react with DEDNPP, compared to powder GOIMZ1. This can be more pronounced since GOIMZ2 reacts concomitantly with both sides of the substrate (deposition on both sides). Even if we compare thin film GOIMZ with previous GOSH film, that comprises reactive thiol groups, the present studies stands out since IMZ moieties are known for their higher stability in various pH and solvents. On the other hand, thiol groups oxidize easily. 3.2.3 Recycling the nanocatalysts The recycling features of the nanocatalysts were also evaluated as shown in Fig. 11 . For GOIMZ1, the same reaction medium containing the nanocatalysts were reused, without separating the solid. Hence, upon ending of a reaction with DEDNPP, a new aliquot of DEDNPP was added, and the subsequent reaction was followed, not being affected by the products from the previous reaction. Fig. 11 presents the photographs of GOIMZ1 before reacting and after 3 cycles, along with rate constants, that evidence that the nanocatalyst can be efficiently reused. For GOIMZ2, the substrate was removed from the solution washed and reused in a new reaction cycle as illustrated in Fig. 11, along with photographs that show the color change upon reaction completion, i.e., turns yellow due to the phenolic product. Overall, we observe that rate constants don’t vary significantly with reuse, confirming that the functional groups of the nanocatalysts are maintained intact after reaction with DEDNPP. In both cases, the recycling procedure is simple, although with GOIMZ2, handling and washing the film is easier. We highlight that the thin film stays adhered to the substrate efficiently, since UV–Vis of the solution doesn’t show any characteristic GO bands nor any particulate in the medium. In order to verify any structural change of the catalyst after the reaction, the materials were analyzed by FTIR and Raman spectroscopy. Figs. S3 and S4 illustrates the FTIR and Raman spectra’s before and after the reaction with DEDNPP for GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2 where the presence of the characteristic bands of the amide bond after reaction, confirms that the functional group anchored via amide bond was not lixiviated. 3.2.4 Reactivity towards toxic pesticide Paraoxon Given the high reactivity of the nanocatalysts towards the model OP substrate, DEDNPP, known for its lower stability (half-life = 1 month), we pursued reactions with the highly stable toxic pesticide, Paraoxon (half-life = 1 million years) [3,51]. Results for the reactions with Paraoxon show rate constants of 0.013 and 0.70 g−1 min−1 for GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2, respectively, considering the reactive groups (as done in Table 1). Fig. 12 shows the rate enhancements (kcat/kH2O) with the nanocatalysts, along with other reported catalysts [7,34,52]. Surprisingly, the IMZ-derived GO proposed herein are greatly efficient in cleaving Paraoxon, highlighting GOIMZ2 with 108-fold increments. These results are extremely important since they shed light to novel GO-based sensor and detoxifying agents for OP. In fact, accelerating reactions of highly stable OP such as Paraoxon is challenging, in contrast to the must more reactive DEDNPP. That is why DEDNPP is usually used a model to evaluate potential catalytic, but real-life application can only be accomplished with real less reactive OP. The present study should incite future studies focusing on functionalized GO as a promising scaffold for projecting OP degradation systems. Specially, in the case of GOIMZ2 with its facile handling as a thin film which broadens its application and processability. In fact, sensors targeted for Paraoxon or other OP agents usually are enzymatic-based which limits application [53,54]. 3.2.5 Mechanism for OP cleavage The mechanism expected for the reactions of the nanocatalyst with the OP (DEDNPP and Paraoxon) follows in Fig. 13 . Firstly, we believe the OP are adsorbed on the nanocatalysts backbone via van der Waals interaction attraction since the OP aromatic rings are knowingly hydrophobic. Once the OP is on the GO surface it readily reacts with the IMZ groups anchored. Based on previous mechanistic studies for the reactions of IMZ with various OP (including DEDNPP [56] and Paraoxon [22]), we expect that the IMZ groups on GOIMZ surface attacks the phosphorus atom via the nitrogen atom with lone pair. The phosphorylated intermediate is highly unstable due to the labile NP bond [37], which then hydrolyses, regenerating the nanocatalysts and forming a phosphoric acid derivative. This mechanism occurs similarly in enzymatic active sites [57], thus the nanocatalysts can be considered artificial enzymes and can potentially be designed for this purpose seeking therapeutic or sensing applications. This can be particularly interesting using the thin film catalysts as “nanoenzymes”. Finally, we don’t rule out possible contributions of the oxygenated groups on GOIMZ surface to the reactions, for example, by hydrogen bonding of hydroxyl groups with the oxygen phosphoryl group, which stabilizes the transition state, hence, catalyzing the process. These possible interactions also account for the synergistic effect of the nanocatalysts mentioned above and agree with the enzymatic-like nature of the proposed catalysts. 4 Conclusions Herein, a novel approach to anchor IMZ groups on GO through highly stable amide linkage is proposed, obtained as powder (GOIMZ1) and thin film (GOIMZ2). GOIMZ2 presented a higher degree of functionalization, 46% (in mass) in contrast to GOIMZ1 (22%). IMZ moieties have many potential applications such as complexing metal agent [58], CO2 sorption [59] and biosorbents for heavy metals [60] but we focused on its catalytic activity towards OP degradation. The model substrate DEDNPP and the toxic pesticide Paraoxon were successfully degraded and to illustrate its efficiency, Fig. 14 , presents their life-times in the presence of the nanocatalysts. For DEDNPP, it’s spontaneous cleavage (in water) that takes about 15 days is reduced to 4 days and 1.8 h in the presence of GOIMZ1 and GOIMZ2, respectively. More impressively, for the least reactive Paraoxon that has an estimated life-time of 516 million years spontaneously, the nanocatalysts are able to promote the degradation in 1 month for GOIMZ1 and approximately 13 days for GOIMZ2. The nanocatalysts were consecutively recycled, maintaining its activity, which was also confirmed from post-reaction characterizations (FTIR, Raman, SEM). Moreover, the nanocatalysts show a synergistic effect, evidencing an enzymatic-like character, thus can be featured as “artificial nanoenzymes”. The materials proposed have potential as efficient detoxifying agents for eliminating stocks of chemical warfare and pesticides. Especially the thin film GOIMZ2 has potential for designing sensors for monitoring OP since it can be readily handled, washed and reused, just by immersing the film into the contaminated medium. Overall, chemical functionalization of GO showed to be a powerful tool to degrade OP (detoxify) and also to generally design artificial enzymes, i.e. nanoenzymes that are a hot topic nowadays [61–64]. The interfacial functionalization in order to obtain thin film is also of increasing interest, since it leads to easily “processable” materials that can be handled for example on plastic substrates, foreseeing simple sensors. coredata.dc:description: Promoting efficient organophoshate (OP) destruction has been of increasing interest, mainly due to their highly toxic nature and broad use as agrochemicals and chemical warfare. It is known that OP destruction can only be accomplished in the presence of catalysts, since they are knowingly stable. Hence, multifunctional materials have been targeted for this purpose since they can combine catalytic sites with features that enable easy handling, sensor projection for monitoring misuse and even large-scaled detoxification methods. Herein, we developed nanocatalysts derived from graphene oxide, which comprises reactive imidazole groups anchored by covalent functionalization. Two approaches were adopted: (i) a mild aqueous reaction leading to a powder, namely GOIMZ1; and (ii) a liquid/liquid interfacial functionalization, resulting in the thin film GOIMZ2. The nanocatalysts were applied in the destruction of OP and in the case of the toxic pesticide Paraoxon, impressive rate enhancements were obtained (108-fold). Both catalysts were consecutively recycled, maintaining overall characteristics. We highlight the feasible handling of the nanocatalysts, that in the case of the powder, it can be easily filtered, washed and reused. For the thin film, the handling is even more practical, since it can be immersed in the contaminated media and separated easier than the powder. Overall, we show novel imidazole-derived nanocatalysts with promising catalytic efficiency towards OP destruction, which have potential for projecting sensors and detoxification processes, especially with the thin films.
coredata.dc:title: Imidazole-derived graphene nanocatalysts for organophosphate destruction: Powder and thin film heterogeneous reactions
